Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the impact of getting rid of the filibuster by stating that it would be "the end of the Senate as it was originally devised and created going back to our Founding Fathers."
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support or evidence to back up the assertion that getting rid of the filibuster would fundamentally change the Senate.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the Senate was originally devised and created with the filibuster in mind, which is not supported by historical evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by the expert that the filibuster was not part of the Senate rules when it was created and only became an issue in the mid-1800s.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the filibuster was not part of the Founding Fathers' constitutional vision for the Senate, as stated by the expert.
Falters at times: The claim falters in accurately representing the historical origins and development of the filibuster in the Senate.
